Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Mighty Joe Young''' (September 23, 1927 – March 27, 1999[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1998.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com - accessed May 2009]) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[guitarist]].{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Du Noyer | year= 2003 | title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music | edition= 1st | publisher= Flame Tree Publishing | location= Fulham, London | isbn= 1-904041-96-5 | page= 181}} Born '''Joseph Young''' in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], [[Louisiana]], he died in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. Though born in Louisiana, Young was raised in [[Milwaukee]]. He first began playing in the early 1950s by singing in Milwaukee [[nightclub]]s. By the mid-1950s, Young had recorded his first song for Jiffy Records in Louisiana. Before Young became known for his contributions to blues, he was training to become a boxer. Young worked as a [[sideman|sidemen]] in Chicago starting the 1950s.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 194–195 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} He worked with [[Otis Rush]] and his band in the 1960s, and played on [[Magic Sam]]'s [[album]]s, ''[[West Side Soul]]'' and ''[[Black Magic (Magic Sam album)|Black Magic]]''. His album ''Blues with a Touch of Soul'' came out on [[Delmark Records]] in 1971. Young also worked with [[Billy Boy Arnold]], [[Jimmy Rogers]], and [[Willie Dixon]]. Young's [[song]], "Turning Point", appeared in the [[Michael Mann (director)|Michael Mann]] feature [[film]], ''[[Thief (film)|Thief]]'' (1981). Young died in March 1999 at the age of 71 as a result of complications of surgery. ==Discography== *''Blues with a Touch of Soul'' ([[Delmark Records|Delmark]]) - 1971 *''Legacy of the Blues, Vol. 4'' ([[Sonet Records|Sonet]]) - 1972 *''Chicken Heads'' ([[Ovation Records|Ovation]]) - 1974 *''Mighty Joe Young'' ([[Ovation Records|Ovation]]) - 1976 *''Bluesy Josephine'' (Black and Blue) - 1976 *''Love Gone'' ([[Ovation Records|Ovation]]) - 1978 *''Live at the Wise Fools Pub'' (Aim Trading Group) - 1978 *''Mighty Man'' ([[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]]) - 1997 ==See also== *[[List of nicknames of blues musicians]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=11574 Mini biography at Allaboutjazz.com] * [http://www.wirz.de/music/youngmj.htm Illustrated Mighty Joe Young discography] * [http://elvispelvis.com/mightyjoeyoung.htm Obituaries at Elvispelvis.com] * [http://elvispelvis.com/mightyjoeyoung.htm#bio Mini biography at Elvispelvis.com] {{Authority control|VIAF=100985701}} {{Persondata | NAME = Young, Mighty Joe | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[guitarist]] | DATE OF BIRTH = September 23, 1927 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = March 27, 1999 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Young, Mighty Joe}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:African-American musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Fire Records artists]] [[Category:Musicians from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Ovation Records artists]]
